Where does Floreano work btw?
Is he still connected with any research gro=
ups in any universities? or does he just work for a commercial research lab=
?

And does someone have info about Nolfi as well? The guy who did a lot of=
 research with Floreano. He was the co-author of "Evolutionary Robotics" bo=
ok as well if I remember correctly..

Regards,
Umer..


  ----- Original Me=
ssage ----- 
  From: Kenneth Stanley 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: W=
ednesday, July 07, 2004 4:42 AM
  Subject: [neat] Re: GECCO Recap


  There=
's definitely a variety of stuff going on at GECCO and most of 
  it doesn'=
t have to do with ANN's directly, but there were a few 
  papers on evolvin=
g an ANN to do something.  But they were mostly 
  very uninteresting exper=
iments, such as classification.  I think the 
  most interesting neuroevolu=
tion outside of NEAT is coming from 
  Floreano and his group, who do evolu=
tionary robotics using 
  neuroevolution.  Our own group from UT also had s=
everal 
  presentations, including one by Faustino Gomez on transferring 
 =
 neuroevolved controllers to the real world.

  It's true that half of GECC=
O is Genetic Programming.  That's 
  becausee GECCO is a combination of the=
 old GA and GP conferences, 
  which used to be separate.  GP is kind of st=
range in that it's just 
  one method yet it is treated like a whole area. =
 This distinction 
  between GA and GP may be fading though over the long t=
erm as 
  indirect encoding becomes more prominent.

  In fact, attention t=
o indirect encoding was the big thing I noticed 
  changing at this confere=
nce.  For the first time since I started 
  attending 4 years ago, it got a=
 lot of attention and communities are 
  starting to form.  People seem to =
have suddenly taken notice that 
  it's going to be a big deal.

  Coevolut=
ion is also getting a lot of attention, but mostly at a more 
  theoretical=
 level than practical.  Still, there was interesting work 
  on cooperative=
 and competitive coevolution, which are definitely 
  both relevant to neur=
oevolution, and most of the leaders in this 
  area go to GECCO.

  ken



=
  --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
  > On Tue,=
 06 Jul 2004 21:04:55 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
  wrote:
  > > Did =
you discover any new NEAT or NEAT like research going on or 
  any
  > > in=
teresting commercial connections?
  > 
  > Not really.
  > 
  > I attended =
a "Genetic Algorithms in Industry" tutorial, which 
  actually
  > turned o=
ut to be two guys from Dow Chemical, so it was 
  really "Genetic
  > Algor=
ithms in the Chemical Industry".  They spoke in very vague 
  terms
  > for=
 the first half hour, and when they finally put some data up on 
  the
  > =
slides, when someone asked what they were representing, they 
  mumbled
  >=
 something about how they couldn't say what the graphs actually 
  showed
 =
 > because it was proprietary.
  > 
  > GECCO is apparently a fusion of dif=
ferent conferences, and it 
  seemed
  > to me that many more of the papers=
 and workshops/tutorials were 
  geared
  > more toward Genetic Programming=
 than any other use of GAs.
  > 
  > There was an interesting presentation =
in my LBP session by a guy 
  from
  > a company that had successfully used=
 GP techniques to identify
  > unexploded ordnance in military artillery ra=
nges that were to be
  > converted to civilian use.  I spoke to another guy=
 from somewhere
  > called Aerospace Corp who said he was skeptical of ANNs=
 and mostly
  > looking for GP-based approaches to analyzing aerial and sat=
ellite
  > photography.  It seems to me that ANN-based approaches to these =

  sorts
  > of fuzzy recognition problems would be more promising than GP
=
  > approaches...so if anything I got a lot of ideas about potential
  > co=
mmercial connections, if anything.
  > 
  > Maybe Ken or Joseph had differe=
nt experiences, though.
  > 
  > Derek
